metadata.name: Professional Editing
metadata.description: Professional editing practices and distinctions including copy editing, line editing, structural editing, and developmental editing. Includes polar inverse concepts for detecting when editing is NOT happening properly or when harmful editing behaviors occur. These concepts enable interpretability of different levels and types of text improvement work.
metadata.author: hatcat-team

candidates.definition: The systematic improvement of written content by trained editors, encompassing multiple levels from mechanical correction to substantive development

positive_examples: Professional editing transformed the rough manuscript into a polished book.
The editing process involved multiple passes: developmental, line, copy, and proofreading.
Professional editors bring expertise in grammar, style, structure, and audience expectations.
Editorial work requires balancing author voice with reader needs.
training_hints.disambiguation: Systematic professional improvement of text, not casual revision

candidates.definition: Correcting errors in grammar, spelling, punctuation, and usage while ensuring consistency in style, terminology, and formatting

positive_examples: Copy editing caught the inconsistent hyphenation of 'e-mail' vs 'email' throughout the manuscript.
The copy editor queried the author about the discrepancy between dates on pages 45 and 112.
Copy editing enforced the house style for number formatting and citation format.
Copy editing corrected subject-verb agreement errors and dangling modifiers.
training_hints.disambiguation: Systematic correction for accuracy and consistency, not just error-spotting

candidates.definition: Failing to catch errors during editing, or introducing new errors through careless changes, resulting in degraded text quality

positive_examples: Error propagation: the model's edit introduced a subject-verb disagreement that wasn't in the original.
The revision propagated errors by copying a misspelled name throughout the document.
Editing negligence failed to catch the inconsistent date formats already present in the text.
Error introduction: the 'correction' changed a correct technical term to an incorrect one.
training_hints.disambiguation: Specific failure to maintain or improve quality through editing

candidates.definition: Improving prose at the sentence and paragraph level for clarity, flow, rhythm, and word choice without changing content or structure

positive_examples: Line editing transformed 'It was a situation that was very difficult' into 'The situation proved difficult.'
The line editor varied sentence length to improve rhythm and reader engagement.
Line editing addressed wordiness, replacing 'due to the fact that' with 'because.'
Line editing preserved the author's voice while enhancing clarity and impact.
training_hints.disambiguation: Craft-level prose improvement, not mechanical correction or structural change

candidates.definition: Editing that inappropriately changes the author's distinctive voice, tone, or style, imposing the editor's preferences rather than serving the work

positive_examples: Voice distortion: the model rewrote the casual, conversational essay in formal academic prose.
The edit distorted the author's voice by removing the characteristic dry humor throughout.
Style imposition replaced the author's short punchy sentences with the model's preferred complex ones.
Voice overwrite made the memoir sound like a corporate report rather than personal reflection.
negative_examples: The writing didn't sound like the author.
training_hints.disambiguation: Inappropriate alteration of authorial voice, not legitimate style editing

candidates.definition: Reorganizing content for logical flow, coherence, and effectiveness, including reordering sections, strengthening transitions, and ensuring argument progression

positive_examples: Structural editing moved the backstory from chapter one to chapter three for better pacing.
The structural edit recommended splitting the overlong middle section into two chapters.
Structural editing identified that the argument's strongest point was buried in paragraph twelve.
The editor's structural pass added signposting and transitions between major sections.
training_hints.disambiguation: Purposeful reorganization for effectiveness, not arbitrary rearrangement

candidates.definition: Editing that disrupts logical flow, breaks argument progression, or creates organizational confusion through poorly considered changes

positive_examples: Structural incoherence: the model moved a paragraph that broke the cause-effect chain of the argument.
The edit created structural incoherence by separating the setup from its payoff across distant sections.
Organizational disruption placed the conclusion before evidence that it depended on.
Flow disruption resulted from removing a transitional paragraph without replacing its connective function.
training_hints.disambiguation: Editing-induced organizational damage, not pre-existing structural problems

candidates.definition: Shaping a work at the conceptual level, addressing scope, approach, argument, audience, and overall vision, often requiring significant rewriting

positive_examples: Developmental editing advised narrowing the book's scope from 'all of history' to 'the Renaissance.'
The developmental editor suggested adding a chapter on practical applications for the target audience.
Developmental editing identified that the protagonist lacked a clear motivation arc.
The dev edit recommended shifting from academic to general-audience tone throughout.
training_hints.disambiguation: High-level shaping of work's vision and approach, not just structural reorganization

candidates.definition: Editing that expands the work's scope beyond its intended boundaries, adds tangential content, or drifts from the original vision without authorization

positive_examples: Scope creep: the model added three paragraphs on tangentially related topics not in the original request.
Vision drift occurred when the edit expanded a focused how-to into a sprawling philosophical treatise.
Unauthorized expansion added detailed background information that diluted the document's impact.
The edit introduced scope creep by addressing objections the author deliberately chose not to cover.
training_hints.disambiguation: Unauthorized expansion beyond intended scope, not legitimate development

candidates.definition: Ensuring consistent voice, tone, and stylistic choices throughout a document or across multiple contributors

positive_examples: Style harmonization unified the tone across twelve different chapter contributors.
The editor harmonized the inconsistent levels of formality between sections.
Style harmonization smoothed the shift from conversational to technical voice mid-document.
Harmonizing style ensured the ghostwritten chapters matched the author's established voice.
training_hints.disambiguation: Deliberate unification of stylistic elements, not mere consistency checking

candidates.definition: The process of evaluating, prioritizing, and integrating editorial feedback and reviewer comments into a revised draft

positive_examples: Feedback incorporation required balancing conflicting reviewer suggestions.
The author incorporated structural feedback while pushing back on voice changes.
Effective feedback incorporation addresses the underlying concern, not just the surface suggestion.
The revision memo explained which feedback was incorporated and the rationale for declined suggestions.
negative_examples: Changes were made based on comments.
training_hints.disambiguation: Strategic evaluation and integration of feedback, not mechanical compliance

candidates.definition: The professional discernment required to make editorial decisions, balancing rules, context, author intent, and reader needs

positive_examples: Editorial judgment recognized that the sentence fragment was intentional for stylistic effect.
The editor's judgment balanced house style against preserving the author's distinctive voice.
Editorial judgment determined which inconsistencies were errors versus intentional variations.
Good editorial judgment knows when to query the author versus making silent corrections.
training_hints.disambiguation: Contextual professional discernment, not rule-following or arbitrary choice

candidates.definition: Making editorial changes beyond appropriate scope, overriding author intent without justification, or imposing preferences where restraint is warranted

positive_examples: Editorial overreach: the model rewrote passages that were intentionally informal as part of the author's style.
Over-editing changed the argument's conclusion to one the model preferred.
Editorial imposition replaced the author's cultural references with ones the model found more universal.
Boundary violation occurred when the edit 'corrected' a dialect feature that was authentically rendered.
training_hints.disambiguation: Inappropriate exercise of editorial power, not just extensive editing

candidates.definition: The working relationship between author and editor involving communication, negotiation, and shared commitment to improving the work

positive_examples: Author-editor collaboration established shared goals and boundaries before the edit began.
The collaborative relationship allowed for frank discussion of the manuscript's weaknesses.
Effective author-editor collaboration respects the author's ownership while leveraging editor expertise.
The collaboration evolved as trust built through successive revision rounds.
negative_examples: The author and editor worked together.
training_hints.disambiguation: Structured professional collaboration, not mere interaction

candidates.definition: Editing changes that alter, misrepresent, or obscure the author's intended meaning, whether through poor word choice, structural changes, or contextual removal

positive_examples: Meaning distortion: the model's synonym substitution changed 'might consider' to 'should definitely.'
The edit distorted meaning by removing a crucial 'not' when condensing the sentence.
Semantic distortion resulted from replacing a technical term with an imprecise colloquial equivalent.
Intent misrepresentation occurred when the edit changed hedged language to definitive claims.
training_hints.disambiguation: Editing-induced meaning change, not clarification of ambiguous original
